subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
{{liushu|ic}} : A needle {{zh-l|*ä‡‚}} (abbreviated to {{zh-l|*ç«‹}}) going through a slave's eye. In ancient China, slaves were blinded. Compare {{zh-l|*æ°‘}}.

It is also possible that it is a {{Han compound|ç«‹|é‡|c1=s|c2=p|ls=psc|nocap=y}}. The bottom component is unrelated to {{zh-l|*é‡Œ}}.

Original meaning was â€œboy servantâ€.

This is rebutted in {{zh-ref|Sagart (2008)}}, who cited the wide distribution of the sense â€œmagician; sorcererâ€ in Chinese and the secondary meaning of {{lang|zh|ç«¥}} as â€œservant; messengerâ€, describing the resemblance between the Min and Austroasiatic terms as â€œundoubtedly fortuitousâ€.
